description: Borrowed from Latin submergere, from sub (“under”) + mergere (“to plunge”). Surface analysis is sub- +‎ merge.

verbs.description: submerge (third-person singular simple present submerges, present participle submerging, simple past and past participle submerged)

examples: The submarine submerged in the water.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To put into a liquid; to immerse; to plunge into and keep in.
examples: In films many people are murdered by being submerged in swimming pools.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative, in the passive) To engulf or overwhelm.
examples: Because of the death of his father, he is submerged in sorrow.
